;新加坡航空公司加入了为所有人提供免费机上 Wi-Fi 的少数航空公司行列乘客，从 7 月 1 日起，客户将能够浏览和上网，而无需支付通常的费用或数据限制。

;

;长期以来，空中互联网一直是一项尴尬和混乱的额外费用，通常比它是值得的，即使有的话，而且通常仍然是那些花钱买头等舱或商务旅客座位的人的专属。

;

;这对乘客来说从来都不是一件容易的事，这是富裕的城市国家的旗舰航空公司所拥有的

;

;虽然与 Covid 封锁相比上网时间有所减少，但当人们常常无事可做时，全球 50 亿普通互联网用户每天仍在网上冲浪和滚动的时间超过 6 小时根据 We Are Social（一家跟踪网络和社交媒体使用情况的英国企业）的数据，到 2022 年。

;

;与此同时，航空乘客数量正在反弹。根据国际航空运输协会的数据，2023 年 4 月全球客运量恢复到 Covid 前水平的 90%，这意味着世界有望恢复到 2019 年的 45 亿人次，也就是大流行开始的前一年并随之对旅行施加限制。

;

;将两个和两个放在一起，新加坡航空公司等航空公司正在寻求免费 Wi-Fi 作为影响乘客决定搭乘哪家航空公司航班的一种方式

;

;新西兰航空公司被评为全球最佳航空公司；新加坡一流

;

;“在当今这个连接日益紧密的世界，高速机上 Wi-fi 连接是我们客户最重要的需求之一，”该航空公司的负责人 Yeoh Phee Teik 说。客户体验高级副总裁。

;

;乘客必须注册该航空公司的免费加入忠诚度计划才能使用 Wi-Fi，这类似于其他一些免费提供 Wi-Fi 的航空公司卡塔尔航空公司和达美航空公司等 Wi-fi 运营着他们的系统。

;

;新加坡航空公司表示，该优惠将适用于其 136 架飞机中的 129 架，但据称是 7 架波音 737-800 NG 除外“未启用 Wi-fi”。

;沙特阿拉伯决定从下个月开始每天减少 100 万桶石油产量是分析师表示，预计这将打击最大的燃料消费国亚洲，但此举也可能成为该地区可再生能源发展的催化剂。

;

;沙特阿拉伯承诺的自愿减产是沙特阿拉伯更广泛协议的一部分石油输出国组织 (OPEC) 及其包括俄罗斯在内的盟友将减产延长至 2024 年，以提振低迷的油价。

;

;基准布伦特原油价格在亚洲时段上涨 0.6% 至每桶 76.80 美元周一交易时间。

;

;“沙特阿拉伯的决定势必会推高价格，使其回到更接近每桶 80 美元的门槛。大宗商品数据和分析公司 Kpler 的首席原油分析师 Viktor Katona 表示，事实上，这将影响亚洲的石油进口国，美元走强会加剧这种情况。

;

;在欧盟禁运之后，亚洲获得了大部分俄罗斯深色燃料– 中国、印度是主要进口国

;

;俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后，能源匮乏的亚洲首当其冲地面临着石油供应波动的冲击。中国和印度这两个最大的消费国试图通过抢购打折的俄罗斯石油供应来缓解影响。

;

;印度从俄罗斯进口石油——印度是包括美国在内的四边安全集团的成员，澳大利亚和日本 - 已邀请西方审查。但沙特阿拉伯的减产表明他们可能别无选择。

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯 (Antony Blinken) 将于 6 月 6 日访问该国，这是他自德黑兰以来首次访问该国。在北京的斡旋下，利雅得同意恢复外交关系。去年，沙特阿拉伯回绝了美国对欧佩克减产的批评。

;

;“沙特阿拉伯在欧佩克决策中发挥带头作用，看来他们不会被西方舆论所困扰，”Gnanansekar 说Thiagarajan，Commtrendz Research 主管。

;

;欧佩克不太可能听从西方的压力，并可能会进一步减产，以在需求开始随着全球经济衰退之风开始下滑的情况下为价格提供底线，他补充说。

;

;

;

;但是，由于莫斯科承诺每天减产 50 万桶，因此印度和中国等消费大国可能无法通过增加从俄罗斯的进口来替代日益减少的石油供应分析师表示，从 2 月到今年年底。

;

;澳新银行周一的一份报告称，石油市场预计将在今年下半年大幅收紧，布伦特原油价格可能达到 100 美元/桶

;

;由于替代品很少，观察家说，亚洲国家将不得不加强可再生能源的发展。

;

;“这将鼓励他们寻找替代能源，要么通过自己生产更多石油或加速转向可再生能源，”能源经济与金融分析研究所 (IEEFA) 亚太区债务市场研究和利益相关者参与负责人 Christina Ng 表示。

;

;“短期内，亚洲国家面临的挑战是，供应链还不足以推动可再生能源的大规模推广，”她说。

;

;亚太地区供应 10-15根据 IEEFA 上周四发布的一份报告，中国占全球石油和天然气需求的 %，同时也是最大和第二大石油和天然气消费国。报告称，该地区的大多数石油和天然气公司缺乏脱碳的详细计划，并对新能源持观望态度。

;

;零目标和收入多元化战略，[但大多数]处于脱碳的早期阶段，没有详细的实施计划，”它说。

;

;另一方面，越来越多的金融机构正在加入全球联盟致力于减少化石燃料运营的融资，包括放弃对上游生产的新直接投资。

;

;“从中长期来看，我们认为市场将有动力关注可再生能源，”IEEFA 的Ng 说。

;

;然而，到目前为止，可再生能源在该地区的发展情况喜忧参半，中国等一些国家遥遥领先。

;

;中国在清洁能源领域处于世界领先地位Climate Energy Finance 驻悉尼主管蒂姆·巴克利 (Tim Buckley) 表示，能源投资约为美国的四倍。

;

;印度也在为大规模国内太阳能制造做准备，但过去三年的交付量落后的目标。巴克利说：“因此，需要提高交付量，以符合纳伦德拉·莫迪 (Narendra Modi) 政府的宏伟愿望。”

;

;东南亚有一些亮点，例如越南和菲律宾。另一方面，日本和韩国在海上风电方面已经落后，而台湾的雄心受到太阳能土地不足和海上风电成本高的阻碍，他说。

;

;“所以进步是零散的，但前景非常重要，特别是在能源安全得到额外重视和所有化石燃料成本三年恶性通货膨胀的情况下，”巴克利说。

;中国大陆大城市出现了一个新的小众职业——宠物侦探，这要归功于近年来养宠物的人越来越多。

;

;大多数宠物侦探都是独自工作，或者只有几个同事一起工作，根据案件的难易程度，每个案件的收费在 3,000 元人民币（420 美元）到 30,000 元人民币之间据《中国青年报》报道，寻找并归还走失的动物。

;

;来自中国中部河南省郑州市的宠物侦探严智勇说，在接到命令后，他将与一到两名配备装备的同事一起前往现场头灯、手电筒、夜视镜、网和笼子，以帮助捕捉丢失的宠物，通常是猫和狗。

;

;“逻辑分析和现场推理能力在我们的工作中很重要。寻找丢失的宠物的方法多种多样，”严某说。

;

;有一次，他接到一户人家的电话，他们住在一栋居民楼的7楼，家里的宠物猫丢了。闫说，他和队员们到达公寓后的第一件事就是判断这只猫是逃跑了还是藏在了大楼的某个地方。

;

;“根据猫留下的痕迹，比如走廊上的脚印，角落里留下的头发，我们猜测可能在7楼和11楼之间的某个地方，”严说。 “终于在8楼找到了。”

;

;在另一个案例中，严的团队发现一只三个月大的猫被困在通风区。他们派了一名侦探，在他的腰上绑上绳子，从两个直径为 50 厘米的洞里爬过去，才把它救了出来。

;

;“寻找宠物的过程很有趣。就像做一名普通的侦探一样，需要注意很多通常被忽视的细节，”严说。

;

;吴丽蕾在北京拥有一家宠物侦探社。四年来，他的团队在北京、上海、武汉等全国多个城市搜寻并发现了5000只宠物。

;

;“对于不同种类、不同年龄的宠物，我们寻找的方向也不同， ”吴说。 “侦探工作靠的是经验，但更重要的是要熟悉动物的习性和特点。”

;

;吴说，如果找不到合适的人，他们只会收取“基本服务费”丢失的宠物。

;

;“在很多情况下，寻找和救助宠物的代价远高于购买一只宠物。将宠物视为家庭成员的客户非常看重与‘毛孩子’之间的纽带，”吴说。

;

;根据中国农业出版社的一份报告，估计有 1.17 亿只宠物被饲养截至 2022 年底，中国大陆城市宠物饲养量同比增长 4%。

;

;咨询公司艾媒咨询表示，去年中国宠物经济增长 25%，达到 5000 亿元人民币（70 美元）十亿）。该公司预测，到 2025 年，该市场将激增至 8110 亿元人民币。

;由于缺乏融入社会的机会，香港少数族裔女性处于弱势地位，一个关注团体在社区中的三名年轻女孩据称被她们的母亲杀害后发出警告，她们的母亲据说面临婚姻问题。

;

;Zubin Foundation，一家致力于改善边缘化成员生活的慈善机构少数族裔群体表示，其 213 名客户中有 80% 在一份衡量焦虑和压力等心理困扰的调查问卷中被归类为“严重”或“极度严重”。

;

;在 3 月份调查的 213 名受访者中, 85% 是女性，其中大多数是巴基斯坦人，其次是印度人和尼泊尔人。

;

;在接受该慈善机构咨询服务的人中，近四分之一的人表现出自杀或自残的风险，该组织

;

;它补充说，常见症状包括焦虑、抑郁和愤怒管理，患者大多遇到家庭冲突、创伤史或家庭管理压力。

;

;周一，一名没有精神疾病记录的 29 岁印度女子因涉嫌在深水埗一个劏房内用枕头闷死三个年幼的女儿而被捕。大约一年前，她在怀疑丈夫有外遇后搬到了那里。

;

;香港非政府卫生组织培训人员帮助少数族裔居民

;

;基金会创始人兼首席执行官 Shalini Mahtani 说许多与该慈善机构合作的年轻少数民族妇女在谈论婚姻破裂或心理健康时感到羞愧，她们独自承受着痛苦。

;

;“我们的许多客户实际上是通过强迫婚姻和包办婚姻与他们的亲戚结婚，这不是真正的恋爱情况，”Mahtani 说。

;

;“生女孩也会给她们带来压力，因为她们不想让女儿重复痛苦的循环。

;< p>;“缺乏教育、机会和接触以及文化限制不允许他们做某些事情，例如 [在外面找工作]。他们不能向任何人谈论他们的一些问题。”

;

;她说当局没有完全理解少数民族社区的独特需求，并补充说他们的声音应该被纳入政策制定，特别是在少数民族的工作中房屋委员会、医院管理局和社会福利署。

;

;“现在是政府鼓励非政府组织在其董事会中加入少数族裔成员的时候了，这样他们就可以开始了解这个社区，因为如果你不明白，就很难为社区服务，”她警告说。

;

;‘一切都是中文’：香港的少数族裔学生碰壁

;

;周一被问及民政及青年事务局局长麦美娟表示，如果对少数族裔社区有足够的支持而不是采取应对措施，政府一直非常重视此事。

;

;“有目前，香港有八个少数族裔社区支持中心，提供帮助他们融入社会的服务，”Mak 说，增加翻译选项和多语言表格以获取公共服务反映了政府的努力。

;

;她还指出关心团队将加强与有特殊需要的“隐藏”家庭的联系，并为这些家庭提供支持。

;

;基督教难民行动中心经理杰弗里安德鲁斯认为，此类社会服务应该更全面，更相关的非政府组织需要更多资源。

;

;“我们有女性计划，而且已经满员，但我们还有另外 20 名女性想参与其中。没有足够的资源，”他说。

;

;“很多女性想要融入[社会]并积极参与。他们想照顾自己的心理健康和发展。但资源不允许。

;

;“融合在少数民族的日常压力中发挥了作用，因为他们缺乏语言、就业机会等等。

;

;“我个人认为该事件是一个孤立的案例，但我希望这可能会唤醒我们作为一个社区，我们需要为彼此提供更多支持并寻求帮助。”

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 09:20:02 +0800 How a floating hydrogen farm has moved China closer to clean renewable energyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3223032/how-floating-hydrogen-farm-has-moved-china-closer-clean-renewable-energy?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 08:00;

;一组中国研究人员在寻求清洁、可再生能源方面又向前迈进了一步

;

;利用风能和太阳能发电的海上平台开发首次成功尝试无需海水淡化即可利用海水，由深圳大学谢和平研究员领衔，国有的东方电气集团有限公司。

;

;这个被称为“东方一号”的平台锚定在中国东南部福建省沿海海域，能够承受高达波弗特级力 8。

;

;来自海洋的氢燃料？科学家们表示，他们已经找到了一种方法

;

;“它在 5 月的首次运行中成功完成了为期 10 天的连续运行，标志着可再生能源海上制氢前景的良好开端”，国家新闻机构新华社 6 月 3 日报道。

;

;这个 63 平方米（678 平方英尺）的平台结合了制氢系统和稳定的海上风力发电系统。通过将这两个组件结合起来，研究人员创建了一个环保型浮动农场，可以将海水电解成氢气，而不会产生不良副作用或污染。

;

;“该演示实验不仅验证了该设备的抗干扰能力，而且还产生了有价值的数据。该项目是从学术成果向产业化转变的典范案例，”报告称。

;

;平台核心制氢技术的创造者谢的团队首次发表了一篇关于该过程的文章发表在 11 月的同行评审期刊《自然》上。

;

;由于海水的成分复杂，因此处理起来很复杂。它充满了微生物和悬浮颗粒，这往往导致电解效率低下，同时缩短设备的使用寿命。

;

;以前的项目 - 例如荷兰和德国的项目 - 往往依赖于首先淡化

;

;但这种方法增加了制氢过程的复杂性——需要大量的海水淡化设备和大量土地资源，这既增加了制氢成本，也增加了项目建设的难度.

;

;自 20 世纪 70 年代以来，科学家们一直在寻找通过直接电解海水来制造氢气的方法。谢教授团队提供的解决方案被科技部评为2022年中国十大科技进步之一。

;

;同时，东方电气集团帮助该技术实现产业化生产，确保海上风电稳定供应。研究人员表示，浮动电解平台由 10 兆瓦的风力涡轮机提供动力并配备 28 千瓦的储能系统，连续 10 天以接近 100% 的法拉第效率生产氢气。

;

;即使在这些条件下该平台的性能和能耗与实验室条件相当。

;

;科学家表示，在海水中运行 10 天后，该系统仍然保持了令人印象深刻的超过 99.99% 的离子排斥率，生产纯度至少为 99.9 的氢气。

;

;德国气候问题特使会谈中国、合作和 COP28

;

;此外，该平台无需海水淡化，提供了一种具有成本效益的替代方案到目前的工业生产。该技术每公斤（2.2 磅）氢气的成本低至 11.2 元（1.57 美元）——远低于目前天然气制氢的主流成本（每公斤 20 至 24 元）。

;< p>;Xie 表示，该团队现在希望扩大他们的成就。

;

;“我们已经成功整合了海上可再生能源，并在真实而复杂的海洋中实现了海水的无脱盐电解。我们的团队计划开发更高效、抗干扰的制氢系统，并与全球公司一起推动其产业化，”谢说。

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong should empower its young refugees with better education and supporthttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3222797/hong-kong-should-empower-its-young-refugees-better-education-and-support?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 08:15;
;;

;11 岁的巴基斯坦演员 Sahal Zaman 最近获得第 41 届最佳新演员奖香港电影金像奖《向阳面》。他饰演一名年轻的难民，生动地展现了香港难民生活的艰辛。

;

;香港的许多年轻难民，无论是与父母一起逃到这里，还是出生在难民家庭，都在香港长大。

;

;根据入境事务处的数据，截至 2 月 28 日，有 1,437 名年龄在 24 岁或以下的免遣返声请人因免于从香港被驱逐、遣返或移交到另一国家。他们没有香港居留权，也不想被遣返原籍国。在某些情况下，难民要等上 20 多年才能重新安置。

;

;我们上个月发布的研究报告“香港难民青年研究：教育赋权计划”包括深入访谈三名专业人员和六名年轻难民。探讨难民青年面临的学习和生活问题，以及他们在香港的成长和发展，以及他们所获得的支持是否足够。

;

;揭示难民青年不仅经历少数族裔常见的困难社会排斥和自我认同问题等问题，同时也生活在难民身份的束缚中。<​​/p>;

;难民家庭仅靠政府和非政府组织的支持难以满足基本生活费用.难民青年因贫穷而被剥夺了参加许多课外活动的机会，又因旅行限制而无法离开香港参加这些活动。由于缺乏政府对专上教育的补贴，能够继续深造的有才华的难民青年受到阻碍。

;

;那些希望合法工作的人必须向移民局申请就业许可，但过程缓慢.那些不遣返要求被拒绝的人发现更难获得许可证。这阻碍了他们努力摆脱贫困。

;

;他们的苦难可能会导致情绪问题，但难民青年很难找到可以倾诉的朋友。他们往往自卑和自我污名化，将自己与主流社会和社会群体隔离开来。更糟糕的是，他们害怕被欺负而不敢透露自己的难民身份。

;

;尽管如此，这些难民青年仍然认为香港很特别，因为他们有在这个城市长大的朋友和记忆。即使他们在其他地方定居后，香港仍然是他们返回和贡献的首选之地。有难民回港支持香港志愿服务的感人事迹。

;

;政府和社会有责任营造更适合香港难民青年成长发展的环境。我们应该把他们当作本地学生，给予适当的教育和培训。

;

;世界上有很多地方的难民政策比较完善。例如，中国中央政府给予难民儿童（其中大部分被认为是中国血统）与当地儿童相同的公共教育机会。

;

;我建议香港政府促进难民青年教育赋权程序。这将要求学校将难民学生转介给非政府组织进行课外教育和培训，以帮助他们缩小与当地学生的教育差距。

;

;应在不向同龄人透露学生难民身份的情况下提供支持，以防止进一步的排斥和欺凌。理想情况下，这应该由非政府组织主导并得到学校的支持。

;

;政府应提供资金，确保服务质量并建立交流平台，而推荐难民学生的学校应定期评估他们的表现

;

;NGO 主要应定期向政府和学校评估和传播这些学生的表现数据，组织课外活动，帮助他们在社区中应用所学，确保

;

;近年来，社会对假难民问题表示关注。安全局于去年年底推出了一项旨在结束滥用申诉系统的更新删除政策。收紧遣返政策以加强对免遣返声请的处理似乎是合理的；难民一直被批评为社会的负担，并且有人认为，增加支持可能会吸引更多人到香港。

;

;在香港拘留移民不应该像坐牢

;

;但我相信这不太可能。大多数难民在逃离自己的国家之前，对香港的情况知之甚少，即使加强了教育支持，他们在香港的生活仍然充满挑战。

;

;无论是成长还是发展，难民香港的年轻人生活很艰难，却很少有人关注他们。它们通常被视为负担并被贴上负面标签。我希望政府和社会重视他们的发展需要，多关注他们的教育。

;

;如果政府、学校和非政府组织能够共同努力，香港的难民青年可以在更好的环境中成长环境。当他们快乐地定居在别处时，他们将能够更好地适应新家园并追逐自己的梦想。也许有一天，他们会回来为香港做贡献。

;

;中国初创企业 Changing Bio，利用发酵技术从微生物蛋白中提取乳制品一位高管表示，该公司希望利用对环境可持续替代品不断增长的需求，帮助国家实现其气候目标。

;

;

;Changing Bio 的微生物成分称为 Kluvy Protein，源自青海东南边缘的酵母-位于香格里拉镇的青藏高原，是公司产品的蛋白质产地。这些产品在味道和质地上与乳制品完全相同，但不含动物成分。

;< p>;虽然发酵已在食品生产中使用了几个世纪，但随着对全球变暖和对环境可持续蛋白质的需求不断增长的认识，发酵的使用已扩展到其他应用，包括食品技术。

;

;一个反应池每年可生产400吨蛋白质，可满足5000至10000人的蛋白质需求。

;

;去年6月，Changing Bio获得美国获得 2200 万美元的 A 轮融资，据称是中国食品科技公司中规模最大的融资，由 Bits x Bites、Hillhouse Capital、Sherpa Healthcare Partners 等领投。

;

;该公司在中国建立了两个研发中心上海和青岛可生产足够200至300吨奶油和奶酪等替代食品的微生物蛋白粉。 Changing Bio 计划在今年第四季度将其产能扩大 20 倍。

;

;食品科技领域的投资看起来已经出现了巨大的增长。根据 Good Food Institute APAC 去年的一份报告，与全球经济趋势相反，去年对亚太地区发酵蛋白公司的投资猛增了 67%。

;

;中国消费者也表现出渴望另类蛋白质智囊团表示，通过加入他们认为能够以可承受的价格提供高营养价值和食品安全的新食品，使他们的蛋白质供应多样化。

;

;“微生物蛋白质可能成为第三大支柱Changing Bio 的 Luo 说：“除了动物蛋白和植物蛋白之外，未来的蛋白质产业。”

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Hong Kong mall stabbing: authorities urged to overhaul mental health services to provide patients with more community supporthttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3223049/hong-kong-mall-stabbings-authorities-urged-overhaul-mental-health-services-provide-patients-more?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 07:30;
;;

;Hong Kong should overhaul its mental health services by shifting some resources for hospital care to support patients in the community, experts have said, after a man with psychiatric issues was charged with murdering two women in a stabbing attack while another was arrested for allegedly threatening neighbours with knives.

;

;Hector Tsang Wing-hong, interim director of Polytechnic University's Mental Health Research Centre and a psychosocial health professor, on Monday said last week's attack reflected the lack of support for mental illness patients to integrate into society.

;

;“There should be a team, consisting of occupational therapists, social workers, community nurses and psychologists, closely supervising people with severe mental illnesses and providing holistic help,” said Tsang, an occupational therapist who specialises in mental illnesses.

;

;“It is different from hospital settings where more emphasis is put on using medications to stabilise patients' emotions.”

;

;Psychiatric review ordered for Hong Kong man facing 2 counts of murder at mall

;

;He urged the government to reallocate more mental health-related resources from public hospitals to the community, such as by including support services in district health centres, so patients could be taken care of after being discharged.

;

;The call came after two women were stabbed to death in a Diamond Hill shopping centre on Friday. Sources earlier told the Post the suspect suffered from schizophrenia and was hospitalised in 2020, while authorities said he had received treatment at a public specialist outpatient clinic at Kwai Chung Hospital.

;

;Another man with a history of mental illness was arrested on Saturday after he allegedly banged on his neighbours' door and threatened them with a pair of knives.

;

;In a reply to the Post, the Hospital Authority said it had been providing community psychiatric services in recent years through case managers who would arrange regular outreach and home visits. Intensive care teams had been set up in seven hospital clusters since 2011-12 and as of March 31, 430 case managers were following up on 18,100 patients.

;

;Hong Kong shocked by double murder at mall. The Post looks at what you need to know

;

;In 2017, a government report outlined the goal of reducing the ratio of case managers in the public sector treating patients with severe mental illnesses from 1:50 to 1:40 by 2022.

;

;A Legislative Council briefing in April showed authorities had cut the ratio to 1:41, meaning one case manager could be responsible for between 40 and 50 patients.

;

;While the government had an advisory committee on mental health, Tsang said, healthcare sector members were mostly psychiatrists with fewer occupational therapists, who played an important role in community support for mental illnesses.

;

;“Their reviews on mental health policies are not comprehensive enough and most of the resources lean towards public hospitals,” he said.

;

;“As a result, limited resources are put in the community and now tragedy has happened. Doctors will not walk out of consultation rooms and reach out to the community. These are the roles of social workers and occupational therapists.”

;

;As mental health efforts in hospitals, rehabilitation and community care were fragmented, he suggested the government appoint a commissioner to facilitate coordination across different departments and professions.

;

;Professor Paul Yip Siu-fai, director of the University of Hong Kong's Centre for Suicide Research and Prevention, said whenever violent crimes related to mentally ill patients occurred, society might only focus on medical treatment and overlook the need for community support.

;

;“In a medical approach, doctors mostly treat the symptoms of mental illness patients, but not the causes behind their issues,” he said.

;

;“We need a systematic change in mental health policies, instead of simply investing a bit more money in public hospitals whenever tragedies happen, which was what we used to do.”

;

;He suggested in the long term, the government should cope with mental illnesses at an early stage by strengthening education at school, as well as for parents and teachers.

;

;Paul Wong Wai-ching, a clinical psychologist and an associate professor of social work at the University of Hong Kong (HKU), said an official accreditation system should be set up for counsellors to encourage the authorities and non-government organisations to hire more people with a counselling background to help patients with less severe mental illness.

;

;Number of Hong Kong students with mental health woes doubles in 4 years

;

;He said clinical psychologists and education psychologists were covered by the government's Accredited Registers Scheme for Healthcare Professions, but not counsellors.

;

;“Although counsellors' qualifications and training time may not be as high as psychiatrists, psychologists or people with social work training, they can be in charge of patients with less severe mental health issues or mental health advocacy work,” he said.

;

;“Hong Kong should better utilise the existing counsellor manpower.”

;

;He said it could help relieve a shortage of mental health professionals in the public sector.

;

;Eric Chen Yu-hai, a member of the government's Advisory Committee on Mental Health, said collaboration between the public and private sectors should be boosted to make up for a shortfall in psychiatrists.

;

;Official figures showed only 390 psychiatrists worked in the public sector during the 2020-21 financial year.

;

;The private sector has 184, according to the Hong Kong College of Psychiatrists.

;

;Chen, a psychiatry chair professor at HKU, said: “There are very few instances of public-private collaboration that we are aware of. We don't have enough psychiatrists in the city.”

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Beijing must take action to bolster growth, but do not expect drastic moves in the near termhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/article/3222993/beijing-must-take-action-bolster-growth-do-not-expect-drastic-moves-near-term?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 07:00;
;;

;The moment is nearing for Beijing to take forceful measures to save the economy, as the post-coronavirus recovery has proven weak and fragile.

;

;It was only three months ago that the Chinese government's growth target of “around 5 per cent” for 2023 was seen as a conservative estimate amid expectations of a strong rebound. Now that optimism has largely vanished, with investment banks joining together in cutting growth forecasts for the country this year.

;

;Even China's official economic data contains bad signs about the world's second largest economy. The country's purchasing manager index for May, a gauge of factory activity, dropped to its lowest level since December, in a fresh sign of a weak economy on top of high youth unemployment, weak consumer spending and worsening corporate profits.

;

;Without a thriving private economy, China's young workers have no jobs

;

;While it is far from a classic economic crisis, slow growth and pessimism have fuelled talk about whether China has “peaked”.

;

;Beijing's response has been largely muted. The government may need more time to observe and analyse the situation, or maybe the changing of the guard at China's top economic management organs have made it hard to quickly come up with a plan. While economic development remains the ruling Communist Party's central task, work related to security, ideology and social control often wind up taking priority.

;

;But Beijing cannot ignore the country's economic reality. Long-term stability, security and prosperity require steady economic growth, and in the short term, poor economic performance can lead to social problems.

;

;China's poor fiscal situation in some places has started to affect basic public services, with an immediate impact on social stability. For instance, there have been sporadic reports of unpaid doctors and teachers – most of whom are paid from state funds. Salary cuts for government employees in the form of reduced subsidies or bonuses are also not uncommon.

;

;These events lend credibility to speculation that Beijing is discussing plans to propel growth. After all, former Chinese premiers similarly deployed Keynesian stimulus in the past.

;

;Zhu Rongji is remembered for initiating special government bonds in the 1990s, and he approved a bailout of the Big Four state banks by offloading bad loans.

;

;Wen Jiabao has become associated with the “4 trillion yuan stimulus” that he launched in the wake of the 2008 global financial crisis.

;

;Li Keqiang, who repeatedly rejected calls for an all-out stimulus, orchestrated certain spending programmes such as “shanty town renovation” – which is really a more targeted form of economic stimulus.

;

;So even as Premier Li Qiang faces more constraints than his predecessors, there is a general consensus that the government must take action to address anaemic economic growth.

;

;There has been some speculation that the government may borrow from its old playbook by bailing out local government financing vehicles.

;

;One possible scenario involves China Development Bank, which has long played a supportive fiscal role in urbanisation, and has been a key bridge between monetary and fiscal policy. The bank could be allowed to take over the debt of problematic financing vehicles with funds raised by issuing special bonds.

;

;China's four state-owned asset management companies – known as the “bad banks” – could undertake similar tasks of cleaning up the balance sheets of local government financing vehicles.

;

;Relaxing restrictions on buying property could also be in the cards, but this would be piecemeal and gradual so as to avoid overthrowing Beijing's long-standing policy of curbing property speculation.

;

;Separately, given the level of household debt, a large inventory of apartments, and slumping marriage and birth rates, it would be a false hope to think simply cutting mortgage rates or lowering down payments will ignite a new wave of property investment.

;

;At the same time, Beijing knows that these types of supportive policies come at a price. If designed and implemented properly, they can buy the government some time to solve deep-rooted problems. But if rolled out hastily, they can be like, in China's own words, “quenching the thirst by drinking the poison”.

;

;Thus the scope of any economic rescue plan that China might use will be quite moderate.

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 07:20:02 +0800 Small-brained ancient human cousins may have buried their deadhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/africa/article/3223055/small-brained-ancient-human-cousins-may-have-buried-their-dead?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.06 07:07;
;;

;An ancient human cousin may have buried its dead and carved symbols into cave walls, surprising findings for a creature with a small brain.

;

;Fossil remains of the species – named Homo naledi – were uncovered in underground caves in South Africa a decade ago. Now, researchers say they have found evidence that the species was capable of complex behaviour that so far has only been seen in those with bigger brains.

;

;“We are facing a remarkable discovery here” for a species with brains one-third the size of humans, said anthropologist Lee Berger, who led the research funded by the National Geographic Society, where he now works.

;

;Berger and colleagues describe their findings in studies posted online on Monday. The research has not been peer-reviewed yet and some outside scientists think more evidence is needed to challenge what we know about how humans evolved their complex thinking.

;

;“There's still a lot to uncover,” said Rick Potts, director of the Smithsonian's Human Origins Programme who was not involved in the research.

;

;H. naledi is a pretty new addition to the family tree of hominins, which includes our direct ancestors and other extinct relatives who walked on two legs. Berger and his team announced the species in 2015, after a tip from local spelunkers led them to the Rising Star cave system near Johannesburg where they uncovered fossils from at least 15 individuals who lived around 300,000 years ago.

;

;These creatures had some traits in common with modern humans, like legs made for walking upright and hands that could work with objects, said University of Wisconsin-Madison anthropologist John Hawks, a member of the research team. But other features looked more ancient, including their small brains.

;

;In recent years, team members have ventured back into the caves, a tricky descent through tight underground spaces. What is down there shows the species in a new light, they reported.

;

;Earliest known saddle unearthed in woman's 2,700-year-old Xinjiang tomb

;

;One of the new studies describes what researchers say were intentional burial sites. The team uncovered fossil remains of adults and children in shallow holes in the ground, their bodies in a fetal position.

;

;Another study describes a series of marks carved into the cave walls, including geometric patterns and cross-hatched lines.

;

;“This is something that takes a lot of time and effort to do,” said Berger, who led the initial research while at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg.

;

;All of this behaviour would be surprising for a creature whose brain was closer in size to an ape's than a human's, experts said.

;

;Decades ago, we thought Homo sapiens were the only ones who could figure out how to use fire, bury their dead or create art, said Chris Stringer, a human evolution expert at London's Natural History Museum who was not involved in the research.

;

;Since then, we have learned that other groups like Neanderthals also lived complex lives. But those species still had big brains – unlike H. naledi, whose burials would raise further questions about human evolution, Stringer said.

;

;Scientists have not yet been able to identify how old the engravings are. So Potts said the current evidence cannot say for sure whether H. naledi was truly the one to create the symbols, or if some other creature – maybe even H. sapiens – made its way down there at some point.

;

;For study author Agustin Fuentes, an anthropologist at Princeton University, the H. naledi evidence takes the focus off brain size.

;

;“Big brains are still important,” Fuentes said. “They just don't explain what we thought they explained.”

; Tue, 06 Jun 2023 07:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong Science Park unveils zero emissions plan as city eyes transformation into a green tech, finance hubhttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3223045/hong-kong-science-park-unveils-zero-emissions-plan-city-eyes-transformation-green-tech-finance-hub?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;Start-up incubator Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks (HKSTP) has unveiled a plan to achieve a net-zero emissions target by 2045 in a bid to help the city achieve its goal of becoming an international green technology and finance hub.

;

;Under its Net-Zero 2045 Vision, presented on World Environment Day on Monday, HKSTP has set near- and long-term targets covering the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi), the ultimate goal of which is to limit the overall global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

;

;HKSTP's near-term goals – which should be achieved by 2030 – include reductions of 42 per cent in carbon emissions in operations. The targets also include a reduction of 25 per cent in carbon emissions in downstream leased assets such as carbon emission from tenants and waste, and a cut of 52 per cent in carbon emissions intensity per square metre from capital goods, such as embodied carbon emissions.

;

;By making the commitment, HKSTP has become Hong Kong's first statutory body to commit to net-zero by 2045, five years ahead of the city's Climate Action Plan 2050 Carbon Neutrality target.

;

;Hong Kong raises US$6 billion in city's biggest green bond offering

;

;“Hong Kong is fast emerging as a leader and a first-mover in green tech and green finance innovation. We hope our Net-Zero 2045 vision can help lead the way by setting new operating benchmarks and show Hong Kong businesses and industries that Net-Zero is a viable business goal,” said Albert Wong, HKSTP CEO.

;

;“HKSTP is building a green tech and green finance ecosystem to spark a cluster effect to launch climate and sustainability innovations from Hong Kong to the world and vice versa. With more than 100 green tech ventures already, HKSTP believes that creating a virtuous cycle of green innovation and investment will drive sustainability, which further drives even more innovation,” he said.

;

;Currently, HKSTP is drawing up a decarbonisation road map with a key focus on areas such as building energy efficiency, retro-commissioning and retrofitting.

;

;The commitment also underscores HKTSP's support for Hong Kong's initiatives to transform the city into a green technology and finance centre, which were unveiled by Financial Secretary Paul Chan Mo-po in his budget speech in February.

;

;Among the initiatives Chan outlined was a plan to build a green tech “ecosystem” to attract the best people and enterprises, and encourage collaboration in industry, academia and research communities to accelerate commercialisation of innovative technology.

;

;The measures also include help for green projects to obtain capital “more conveniently and flexibly” through innovative financing arrangements on top of traditional channels, and making it easier for new ventures to obtain independent certification for their green credentials – such as carbon emission reduction capacities – which is essential for their fundraising activities.
